title: Hives (Children)
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if your child:
bullets: Has sudden hives with swelling in the face, difficulty breathing or coughing , dizziness , or fainting
Has hives after being exposed to a substance that caused a serious allergic reaction before
Develops hives after a bee sting , new medication , or exposure to a highly allergenic food, such as peanuts

bullets: You have any concerns
The hives seem severe
Home treatment isn't helping

sections.heading: 1. Use an Antihistamine, If Your Pediatrician Approves
content: An antihistamine formulated for children may help with swelling and itching . Call a pediatrician before using an antihistamine in infants or toddlers .

content_blocks.text: An antihistamine formulated for children may help with swelling and itching . Call a pediatrician before using an antihistamine in infants or toddlers .

sections.heading: 2. Remove Allergens
bullets: If the hives are on one part of your child's body, they may have been triggered by something that got on their skin . Wash off your child's body with soap and water.
Change your child's clothes.

items: If the hives are on one part of your child's body, they may have been triggered by something that got on their skin . Wash off your child's body with soap and water.
Change your child's clothes.

sections.heading: 3. Treat the Itch
bullets: Apply calamine lotion, 1% hydrocortisone cream, or a mixture of baking soda and water for itch.
Put your child in a cool bath for 10 minutes.
Put a cold compress or cold pack on itchy areas.

items: Apply calamine lotion, 1% hydrocortisone cream, or a mixture of baking soda and water for itch.
Put your child in a cool bath for 10 minutes.
Put a cold compress or cold pack on itchy areas.

sections.heading: 4. Observe Your Child
content: If your child's symptoms seem to be getting worse, call a doctor.
